clips.title: Syrians in Lebanon: We can neither leave nor stay
clips.leadText: Beirut: Facing a sustained influx of refugees fleeing Syria's civil war, the Lebanese government imposed visa restrictions on Syrians this January. Now, in order for their residence in Lebanon to remain legal, Syrians must fit within one of six narrowly defined residency categories, or obtain sponsorship from an employer...

clips.title: Cold classrooms make school difficult, students say
clips.leadText: Beirut/Zahle: Freezing temperatures have settled over Lebanon during the past month, but children across Lebanon say the classroom is no place to escape the cold. Government officials and school administrators say they lack the necessary funds for adequate fueling, despite appealing year after year to U.N. agencies and private donors to help keep students warm...

clips.title: Rate of C-sections alarmingly high
clips.leadText: BEIRUT: From the beginning of her pregnancy, Abir Mansour knew that she didn’t want a C-section. As the months passed and she grew closer to term, some tried to sway her otherwise with unsolicited advice, such as the woman who told her that a C-section wouldn’t be painful, nor would it upset her sex life like a vaginal delivery would...

clips.title: Cases of contagious hepatitis A reach epidemic levels in Lebanon
clips.leadText: BEIRUT: Health officials say that Lebanon has seen a sharp rise in the number of hepatitis A cases over the past two years. The highly contagious viral infection is spread through oral ingestion of contaminated water and food. “We are living now in a current epidemic of hepatitis A. It has been going on for more than two years,” infectious disease specialist Abdul-Rahman Bizri said...
